Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Chemistry and Vertical Transport of Hox Radical Precursors During the Uintah Basin Winter Ozone Study in Utah
Award.AbstractNarration:
Wintertime ozone pollution in sparsely populated rural areas that have come under the influence of nitrogen oxide and volatile organic compound emissions from hydraulic fracturing natural gas drilling activities is a relatively recent phenomenon. The fact that ozone mixing ratios exceed the federal air quality standard in winter but not in summer poses a scientific puzzle. Weak solar irradiance in mid-winter is expected to lead to a considerable slowdown of photochemistry and consequently low ozone levels. It has been hypothesized that specific environmental conditions, in particular the presence of surface snow, are an important factor in the formation of wintertime ozone. Snow increases surface albedo and, thus, enhances the actinic flux in winter to levels more similar to those in the tropics. However, it appears that this effect only explains part of the high wintertime ozone levels. It has also been hypothesized that snow chemistry can be an efficient source of the hydroxyl and hydroperoxyl (OH + HO2 = HOx) radical precursors nitrous acid (HONO) and formaldehyde (HCHO). Elevated levels of these species could further accelerate the formation of ozone in winter. The weak wintertime solar irradiance and high infrared emissivity of snow also lead to the formation of strong and shallow surface inversions, which can further accelerate ozone formation by concentrating pollutants near the surface.

The Uintah Basin Winter Ozone Study jointly organized by NOAA/ESRL Chemical Sciences Division, Physical Sciences Division, NOAA Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory, and the University of Colorado (http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/csd/tropchem/2012ubwos/) field experiment is planned for the time period of January 15 to March 1, 2012. The measurements to be performed offer a unique opportunity to study polluted wintertime atmospheric chemistry of ozone, as a large number of complementary measurements will be performed by other investigators. The following scientific hypotheses related to wintertime ozone formation will be tested:

- The photolysis of HONO, and to a lesser extent HCHO, are important, if not the dominant primary HOX formation pathways under wintertime conditions.

- Chemistry in the snow or on the snow-covered ground strongly contributes to the mixing ratios of HONO and HCHO, and is thus an important factor for HOX and ozone formation.

- Surface inversions and suppressed vertical mixing play a crucial role in concentrating pollutants in a shallow surface layer, thus accelerating surface ozone formation.

Vertical profile measurements of ozone, nitrogen dioxide, HONO and HCHO will be obtained by Long-Path Differential Optical Absorption Spectrometery. The acquired data, together with data available from other investigators, will be interpreted using established methods.

Activities will be closely coordinated with the Utah Department of Environmental Quality and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 8. The results will thus directly be used to develop mitigation strategies for the ozone pollution found in the Uintah Basin and thus benefit the local population. The results will also benefit other locations with similar problems, such as the Upper Green River Basin, Wyoming. The current expansion of natural gas drilling activities also makes this a timely proposal as the air quality problem found in Utah and Wyoming may soon also occur in other places in the U.S. and Canada. The project will also provide a graduate student a career development opportunity, building on previous experience performing measurements and analyzing trace gas vertical profile data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Air quality remains a common environmental problem in today’s world, impacting the health and wellbeing of the population in the US and worldwide. While air quality has been steadily improving in US cities, rural areas with increased gas and oil drilling activities have seen an increase in the concentration of ozone, one of the main pollutants contributing to air pollution. Ozone is formed in the atmosphere through chemical processes involving hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxides and sunlight. An essential intermediate in ozone formation is the hydroxyl radical, OH, which is also responsible for the removal of hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides. To describe these chemical processes accurately it is essential to quantify the concentrations of OH as well as its precursor molecules and their formation pathways. One of these precursors is nitrous acid, HONO, which upon illumination with solar radiation releases one OH molecule. Under certain conditions this process can significantly influence the concentrations of OH in the troposphere. Nevertheless, our understanding of the atmospheric chemistry of nitrous acid is incomplete. It is currently believed that nitrous acid is chemically formed on surfaces in the presence of nitrogen dioxide or by photolysis of nitric acid adsorbed on these surfaces. Which of these processes dominates and on which surfaces, i.e. ground or aerosol particles, they occur is unclear, and few measurements have been made that address these questions, in particular in rural areas.  

This project, which was performed in collaboration with the National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration’s Earth System Research Laboratory and the Utah Department of Environmental Quality, studied the wintertime chemistry of nitrous acid, HONO, in the Uintah Basin, Utah, a rural area polluted by gas and oil drilling activities. Measurements of the vertical distribution of HONO and its precursor, nitrogen dioxide, were performed using Differential Optical Absorption Spectroscopy. The observations showed that HONO concentrations were largest near the ground during the day and night, while NO2 levels were smaller near the ground at night and showed no clear change with height during the day. These observations strongly imply that HONO is formed at the ground, i.e. predominately on the soil. The smaller NO2 concentrations near the surface indicate that, at night, NO2 is deposited onto the surface, thus indicating a conversion of NO2 to HONO. A chemical HONO mass balance calculation shows that this ground source appears to account for most of the HONO formation above its levels expected based on well-known gas-phase chemistry alone. Surface formation of HONO is thus an important process in this rural environment. Few air quality models currently include surface formation of HONO. The results of this project thus give guidance to future improvements in these models and the observations can be used to validate models in the future. Improved models will ultimately lead to the development of better air pollution mitigation strategies and thus support efforts to improve air quality in polluted rural areas.
